{{TennisEventInfo|2014|Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters| | date=12 – 20 April | edition=108th | draw=56S / 24D | category=[[Masters 1000]] | surface=[[Clay court|Clay]] / outdoor | prize_money=€3,452,415 | location=[[Monte Carlo]], [[Monaco]] | venue=[[Monte Carlo Country Club]] | champs={{flagicon|SUI}} [[Stan Wawrinka]] <ref name="ms">{{cite web|title=2014 Monte Carlo Men's Singles draw|url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/en/scores/archive/monte-carlo/410/2014/draws?matchType=singles|website=www.atpworldtour.com|publisher=[[Association of Tennis Professionals]] (ATP)}}</ref> | champd={{flagicon|USA}} [[Bob Bryan]] / {{flagicon|USA}} [[Mike Bryan]] }}
The '''2014 [[Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters]]''' was a men's [[tennis]] tournament for male professional players, played from 12 April through 20 April 2014, on [[Clay court|outdoor clay courts]]. It was the 108th edition of the annual [[Monte Carlo Masters]] tournament, which was sponsored by [[Rolex]] for the sixth time. It took place at the [[Monte Carlo Country Club]] in [[Monte Carlo]], [[Monaco]].
==Points and prize money== ===Points distribution=== Because the Monte Carlo Masters is the non-mandatory [[Masters 1000]] event, special rules regarding points distribution are in place. The Monte Carlo Masters counts as one of a player's 500 level tournaments, while distributing Masters 1000 points.<ref>[http://www.atpworldtour.com/Rankings/Rankings-FAQ.aspx#requirements Ranking points]</ref>
{|class=wikitable style=font-size:90%;text-align:center |- |style="width:130px; background:#dfe2e9;"|'''Event''' |style="width:80px; background:lime;"|{{Tooltip|'''W'''|Win}} |style="width:85px; background:thistle;"|{{Tooltip| F | Final}} |style="width:85px; background:#ff0;"|{{Tooltip| SF | Semifinal}} |style="width:85px; background:#ffebcd;"|{{Tooltip| QF | Quarterfinal}} |style="width:85px; background:#afeeee;"|Round of 16 |style="width:85px; background:#afeeee;"|Round of 32 |style="width:85px; background:#afeeee;"|Round of 64 |width=85|{{Tooltip| Q | Qualifier}} |width=85|{{Tooltip| Q2 | Qualifying round 2}} |width=85|{{Tooltip| Q1 | Qualifying round 1}} |- !style="background:#ededed;"|Men's Singles<ref name="ATP points">{{cite web|url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/Rankings/Rankings-FAQ.aspx|accessdate=25 February 2013|title=Rankings explained|publisher=atpworldtour.com|}}</ref> |rowspan=2|1000 |rowspan=2|600 |rowspan=2|360 |rowspan=2|180 |rowspan=2|90 |rowspan=2|45 |10 |25 |16 |0 |- !style="background:#ededed;"|Men's Doubles<ref name="ATP points"/> |0 |{{n/a}} |{{n/a}} |{{n/a}} |}
===Prize money=== The total prize money pot for the 2014 competition is €3,452,415, distributed throughout both competitions.

{{Infobox Airline | airline = Africa One | logo = | logo_size = | fleet_size = | destinations = | IATA = - | ICAO = CFR | callsign = - | parent = [[Avient Aviation]] | company_slogan = The Continent's Airline | founded = 29 April 2002 | headquarters = [[Kinshasa]], [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]] | key_people = Frederick Obbo ([[CEO]]) | hubs = | secondary_hubs = | focus_cities = | frequent_flyer = | lounge = | alliance = | website = }}
'''Africa One''' was a privately owned pan-African airline. It was initially based in [[Entebbe]], [[Uganda]], with aircraft [[wet lease]]d from '''Africa One Holdings''', registered in [[Ireland]]. '''Africa One Congo''' was a subsidiary based in [[Kinshasa]]. It is not clear if the same airline or another of the same name was the operator of the [[An-26]] that crashed with high fatality numbers in the DRC in 2007, but most likely it was operated by the company's Congolese subsidiary, because soon after the incident its operations shut down. '''Africa One''' operated in years 2002-2004 and '''Africa One Congo''' operated in years 2002-2007.<ref>[http://www.aerotransport.org ''www.aerotransport.org'' World Airline Databank] retrieved 2010-09-06</ref>
The airline is on the [[List of air carriers banned in the European Union]].
==History== <!-- [[Sudan]]'s New Vision reported that AfricaOne, a Ugandan carrier, suspended operations on the Entebbe-Nairobi route in January 2003, but flights to [[Dar-es-Salaam]], [[Kilimanjaro]] and [[Dubai]], continued.
The AfricaOne country manager for Kenya, Ada Magezi told ''New Vision'' that the flights to Kenya would resume in a week's time.
She said passengers who had booked their flights were passed on to the East Africa Airlines.
AfricaOne was a joint venture between Dairo Air Services (DAS) of Uganda with entrepreneurs from [[Tanzania]] and [[Nigeria]].
<ref>Africaone Stops Flights to Kenya ''Commercial Aviation Today'' 2003-01-31</ref> -->
<!-- Following paraphrased: [[Boeing Capital Corporation]] repossessed two McDonnell Douglas DC-9s from AfricaOne in April 2003. The customer finance arm of the US manufacturer had leased the two aircraft to AfricaOne as well as providing financing for the airline which launched operations in the spring last year. A BCC spokesman says: "From our perspective we have terminated leases for two DC-9s and the aeroplanes have been recovered and we are busy looking for new lessees." BCC has never revealed its investment in AfricaOne but says that it is "seeking to recover some of the lost revenue" from the airline. The company says it secured its investment into AfricaOne against an aircraft.
The carrier operated flights from Entebbe to Dubai, and to Dar es Salaam and Kilimanjaro with its DC-9s. It had planned to launch flights to Lagos, Nigeria with its McDonnell Douglas DC-10-30 aircraft shortly. In February 2003 it suspended service from Entebbe to Nairobi citing losses on the route. At that time, AfricaOne was owned by a Tanzania investor and Uganda company DAS Air Services.
The aircraft were provided by Ireland registered AfricaOne Holdings to the airline on an ACMI (aircraft, crew, maintenance and insurance) basis. UK based businessman and [[DAS Air Cargo]] CEO [[Charles Heather]] took on the CEO role of Africa One Holdings while DAS Air Cargo chairman Capt Joe Roy became chairman of AfricaOne Holdings. Both are also joint shareholders in the holding company.
A "winding up petition" was presented to the High Court in Ireland on 14 March 2003.
DAS Air Cargo CFO David Fisher speaking regarding the concept of Irish service company AfricaOne says: "The AfricaOne concept is a great concept where you have a service company providing aircraft, crew, maintenance and insurance to all the African operators. In order for it to succeed, it needs more than one operator and that is why the African One concept failed." He adds that DAS Air Cargo continues to operate as an independent cargo company serving Africa and that it is separate from AfricaOne.
<ref>Boeing repossesses AfricaOne DC-9s ''Air Transport Intelligence'', April 2003</ref> -->
{{Empty section|date=July 2010}}
==Destinations== Africa One initially was announced 29 April 2002 using [[DC-9]]s to serve Entebbe, [[Lagos]], [[Freetown, Sierra Leone]], and [[Banjul]] [[Gambia]] with bi-weekly service from those cities to London [[Gatwick]]{{Citation needed|date=January 2010}} and [[Dubai]] by [[DC-10]].
==Fleet== Africa One used [[Airbus A320|A320]], [[DC-10]] and [[DC-9]] on their operations, Africa One Congo used [[An-26]] and [[An-32]] equipment operating mainly cargo flights.<ref>[http://www.aerotransport.org ''www.aerotransport.org'' World Airline Databank] retrieved 2010-09-06</ref>
==Accidents and incidents== *[[2002 Africa One Antonov An-26 crash]]: an [[Antonov]] [[Antonov An-26|An-26]] cargo plane faced a rejected takeoff in the DRC capital of Kinshasa, leading to a possible write-off *[[2007 Africa One Antonov An-26 crash]]: an [[Antonov]] [[Antonov An-26|An-26]] cargo plane chartered by [[Malift Air]] crashed into a street market in the DRC capital of Kinshasa shortly after takeoff, killing 51 people.
==Further reading== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20040708150653/http://www.ugandahighcommission.co.ke/newsletter/008_18.htm Airline launch 2004-07-08] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20020805065757/http://www.boeing.com/news/releases/2002/q2/nr_020506g.html archived Boeing announcement 2002-05-06 ] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20020805065757/http://www.africaalmanac.com/50topcompanies.html archived 50 top companies (as of 2002-08-05)] *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/low/business/1958229.stm BBC News] re launch *[http://www.nationaudio.com/News/EastAfrican/29042002/Regional/Regional29.html press release on launch] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20030202202655/http://www.vztlak.cz/doprava/ 28/5 Nove africke aerolinie AfricaOne zahajily provoz lety do Gatwicku z Nigerie a Ugandy (in Czech)]

[[File:CodexWormianus AM 242 fol, bl. 13r.jpg|thumb|240px|<center>Codex Wormianus AM 242 fol.</center>]] The '''Codex Wormianus''' or '''AM 242 fol.''' is an Icelandic [[vellum]] [[codex]] dating from the mid-14th century. It contains an edition of the [[Prose Edda]] and some additional material on poetics, including the [[First Grammatical Treatise]]. It is the only manuscript to preserve the [[Rígsþula]].
The manuscript is believed to have been written in the [[Benedictine]] monastery [[Þingeyraklaustur]] in [[Thingeyri|Þingeyrar]] in northern [[Iceland]] around 1350. It was obtained by the runologist [[Ole Worm]] from the Icelandic scholar [[Arngrímur Jónsson]] in 1628, according to an inscription on the first page of the work. In 1706, [[Árni Magnússon]] obtained the document from Ole Worm's nephew, Christian Worm.<ref name="kuepages">{{cite web | url=http://www.e-pages.dk/ku/621/ | title=AM 242 fol., Codex Wormianus | publisher=[[University of Copenhagen]] | accessdate=21 February 2015}}</ref> Today it remains part of the [[Arnamagnæan Manuscript Collection]] at the [[Arnamagnæan Institute]] in Copenhagen, Denmark.
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://www.e-pages.dk/ku/621/ Online facsimile of AM 242 fol.] by the [[University of Copenhagen]]. *[http://www.menota.org/DIPL_AM-242-fol%7C0-9-4.xml?side=1 Text version] by the Medieval Nordic Text Archive. *[http://www.germanicmythology.com/ProseEdda/AndersonPrologue.html The Extended Prologue] to Snorri's Edda from Codex Wormianus.
[[Category:Old Norse literature]] [[Category:Old Norse prose]] [[Category:Icelandic manuscripts]]

{{Unreferenced|date=March 2007}} {{Politics of the African Union mini|legislature|width=5em}} The '''Committee on Gender, Family, Youths and People with Disabilities''' is one of the ten permanent committees of the [[Pan-African Parliament]]. It concentrates on issues concerning women, family and people and children with disabilities.
Functions of the Committee:
* Consider issues relating to the promotion of gender equality. * Assist Parliament to oversee the development of policies and activities of the Union relating to family, youth and people with disabilities.
Chairperson of the Committee is the Hon [[Bwambale Biira Loice]] ([[Uganda]]).
The Deputy Chairperson is the Hon [[Blandine Sawagogo Ouedraogo]] ([[Burkina Faso]]).
The Rapporteur is the Hon [[Paul Temba Nyathi]] ([[Zimbabwe]]).
[[Category:Permanent Committees of the Pan-African Parliament|Gender]]
{{Africa-stub}}

{{use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{use list-defined references|date=September 2013}} {{Use British English|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox sheep breed | name = Corteno | image = | image_alt = | image_size = 280px | image_caption = | status = {{nobreak|[[FAO]] (2007): endangered-maintained<ref name=barb/>}} | distribution = [[Val Camonica]] | standard = [http://www.assonapa.it/norme_ecc/OVINI-RA_Standard_WEB/Standard-PecoradiCorteno.htm MIPAAF] | type = | use = meat | altname = Pecora di Corteno | country = Italy | maleweight = 70 kg<ref name=aspa3/> | femaleweight = 60 kg<ref name=aspa3/> | maleheight = 77 cm<ref name=aspa3/> | femaleheight = 73 cm<ref name=aspa3/> | skincolor = | woolcolor = white | facecolor = white | horns = hornless in both sexes | note = }}
The '''Corteno''' or {{lang|it|'''Pecora di Corteno'''}} is a [[breed]] of [[sheep]] from the [[Val Camonica]], in the [[province of Brescia]] in [[Lombardy]], northern Italy.<ref name=dad/> It is raised in the [[comune]] of [[Corteno Golgi]], from which it takes its name, and in the neighbouring comuni of [[Edolo]], [[Malonno]] and [[Paisco Loveno]], all lying within the [[Comunità Montana di Valle Camonica]].<ref name=rare/><ref name=bigi/> It is one of the forty-two autochthonous local sheep breeds of limited distribution for which a herdbook is kept by the [[Associazione Nazionale della Pastorizia]], the Italian national association of sheep-breeders.<ref name=aspa/>
==History==
The origin of the Corteno breed is unknown, but is probably shared with that of other lop-eared breeds of the Alpine region such as the [[Bergamasca (sheep)|Bergamasca]], the [[Biellese]] and the [[Lamon (sheep)|Lamon]]. Numbers were estimated at 4000 in 1983, and at about 1600 in 1995.<ref name=bigi/> In 2006 the total number was estimated at 1500, of which 131 were registered in the herdbook.<ref name=rare2/> The conservation status of the breed was listed as "critical" by the [[FAO]] in 2007.<ref name=barb/> In 2013 the number registered for the breed was 295.<ref name=aspa2/>
==Use==
The meat of the Corteno is exceptionally fatty. It is traditionally used to produce Cuz, a local type of preserved meat. Whole carcases of [[Domestic sheep|wether]] [[mutton]] are boiled in a cauldron for five or six hours with salt and a little water; the meat is then put up in [[terracotta]] jars with more salt and sealed with the mutton-fat.<ref name=bigi/>
==References== {{reflist|refs=
<ref name=aspa>[http://www.assonapa.it/Pubblicazioni/Razze-ovine-caprine-Italia/Razze_Ovine_Caprine_Italia.pdf Le razze ovine e caprine in Italia] (in Italian). Associazione Nazionale della Pastorizia: Ufficio centrale libri genealogici e registri anagrafici razze ovine e caprine. p. 66. Accessed September 2013.</ref>
<ref name=aspa2>[http://www.assonapa.it/Consistenze/Cons_razza.asp?Anno=2013&Cod_razza=F8 Consistenze Provinciali della Razza F8 Pecora di Corteno Anno 2013] (in Italian). Associazione Nazionale della Pastorizia: Banca dati. Accessed September 2013.</ref>
<ref name=aspa3>[http://www.assonapa.it/norme_ecc/OVINI-RA_Standard_WEB/Standard-PecoradiCorteno.htm Norme tecniche della popolazione ovina “Pecora di Corteno”: standard della razza] (in Italian). Ministero delle Politiche Agricole, Alimentari e Forestali. Accessed May 2014.</ref>
<ref name=barb>Barbara Rischkowsky, D. Pilling (eds.) (2007). [ftp://ftp.fao.org/docrep/fao/010/a1250e/annexes/List%20of%20breeds%20documented%20in%20the%20Global%20Databank%20for%20Animal%20Genetic%20Resources/List_breeds.pdf List of breeds documented in the Global Databank for Animal Genetic Resources], annex to [ftp://ftp.fao.org/docrep/fao/010/a1250e/a1250e.pdf ''The State of the World's Animal Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture'']. Rome: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations. {{ISBN|9789251057629}}. Accessed May 2014.</ref>
<ref name=bigi>Daniele Bigi, Alessio Zanon (2008). ''Atlante delle razze autoctone: Bovini, equini, ovicaprini, suini allevati in Italia'' (in Italian). Milan: Edagricole. {{ISBN|9788850652594}}. p. 214–215.</ref>
<ref name=dad>[http://dad.fao.org/cgi-bin/EfabisWeb.cgi?sid=0b1613ebf16355cf65f6a05b9a65fe25,reportsreport8a_50012325 Breed data sheet: Pecora di Corteno - Di Corteno]. Domestic Animal Diversity Information System of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations. Accessed September 2013.</ref>
<ref name=rare>Luigi Andrea Brambilla (2005). [http://www.associazionerare.it/images/pdf/pecora%20di%20corteno.pdf Razze zootecniche in pericolo di estinzione: la pecora di Corteno]{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} (in Italian). ''Vita in campagna'' 2005 (3): 51.</ref>
<ref name=rare2>J. Errante, L.A. Brambilla, M. Corti, E. Pastore, R. Leonarduzzi (2006). [http://www.associazionerare.it/images/razze/altri_documenti/le%20razze%20ovine%20arco%20alpino%202006.pdf Le razze ovine autoctone a rischio del Valle d'Aosta, Lombardia, Veneto, Friuli Venezia Giulia]{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} (in Italian). Associazione RARE. Accessed May 2014.</ref>
}}

{{primary sources|date=March 2013}}
The '''cultural monuments of the [[Czech Republic]]''' ([[Czech language|Czech]]: ''kulturní památka'') are [[heritage site|protected properties]] (both [[real property|real]] and [[movable property|movable properties]]) designated by the [[Ministry of Culture (Czech Republic)|Ministry of Culture of the Czech Republic]]. Cultural monuments that constitute the most important part of the Czech [[cultural heritage]] may be declared '''[[national heritage site|national cultural monuments]]''' ([[Czech language|Czech]]: ''národní kulturní památka'') by a regulation of the [[Government of the Czech Republic]].
==Criteria== The criteria for declaring an object a cultural monument, as well as the rules of their protection and management are defined in Act 20/1987 Coll., on State Heritage Preservation.<ref name="law">[http://portal.gov.cz/app/zakony/zakonPar.jsp?idBiblio=37218&fulltext=&nr=20~2F1987&part=&name=&rpp=15 Portál veřejné správy: Zákon 20/1987 Sb., o státní památkové péči] (in Czech)</ref><ref name="translation">[http://www.mkcr.cz/assets/kulturni-dedictvi/pamatky/zakon-o-statni-pamatkove-pe-egrave_i_eng_final.pdf Ministry of Culture of the Czech Republic: English translation of Act 20/1987 Coll.]</ref> The criteria include objects that are an "important record of historical development, way of life and environment of society from the most ancient times to the present day, as a display of creative skills and work of humankind from the various fields of human activities, for their revolutionary, historic, artistic, scientific and technical values, [or] that have a direct relation to important personalities and historic events".
==See also== * [[List of national cultural monuments of the Czech Republic]]
==External links== {{reflist}} * [http://www.npu.cz/en/ National Heritage Institute] * [http://monumnet.npu.cz/monumnet.php MonumNet] - online registry of cultural monuments (in Czech) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130514162848/http://www.mkcr.cz/en/kulturni-dedictvi/default.htm Ministry of Culture of the Czech Republic]: Cultural heritage
[[Category:Cultural heritage of the Czech Republic]] [[Category:National Cultural Monuments of the Czech Republic| ]]
{{czechRepublic-stub}}

[[Rogers Wireless]] |years_active = 1978–2003 |net_worth = |boards = |spouse = {{Marriage|[[Faranak Margolese]]|2000|2017|reason=divorced}}[http://www.orhaorot.022.co.il/BRPortal/br/P102.jsp?arc=2091026 "David Margolese,"] Or Haorot. Accessed May 18, 2018. |children = 3 |parents = |signature = |website = {{URL|http://www.davidmargolese.com/|davidmargolese.com}} }} '''David Margolese''' (born October 24, 1957) is an entrepreneur and a founder of [[Sirius XM Radio]],Andrea Adelson, [https://www.nytimes.com/2001/07/30/business/media-satellite-radio-s-bet-on-dissatisfied-listeners.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm “Satellite Radio’s Bet on Dissatisfied Listeners,”] ''[[New York Times]]'', July 30, 2001. serving as chairman and CEO from 1993 to 2002.Michael Wolff, [http://nymag.com/nymetro/news/media/columns/medialife/3823/ “Cruise Control,”] ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'', September 25, 2000, pp. 30-32. Considered "one of the earliest advocates of pay radio,"Paul Farhi, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/business/1997/05/19/music-from-the-spheres/232253c7-c57c-4681-aac7-5ca0ef95dd6a/?noredirect=on&utm_term=.c8616da0b441 “Music From the Spheres,”] ''[[Washington Post]]'', May 19, 1997. he "effectively created the industry."Simon Houpt, [https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/rob-magazine/radio-flyer/article18417805/ "Radio Flyer,"] ''[[Report on Business|Report On Business Magazine]]'', September 2001, pp. 14-16. ==Early life== Margolese was born and raised in [[Vancouver, British Columbia]]. He attended the [[University of British Columbia]], dropping out after one year. His father, Leonard, also dropped out of college, to sell television sets in the early 1950s, ultimately building a successful television store. ==Cellular== ===Rogers Wireless=== In 1978, at the age of 20, Margolese founded Canadian Telecom, a Vancouver-based radio paging company.Bethany McLean, [http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/fortune_archive/2001/01/22/295563/index.htm “Satellite Killed The Radio Star,”] ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'', January 22, 2001, pp. 94-100. He struggled in his early years as an entrepreneur. In 1980, he changed his company’s focus to what would become the future cellular market. He prognosticated in his 1980 position paper, years before the commercial introduction of cellular and at a time when computers were in use by less than one percent of the public, that cellular "has the potential to become all pervasive." He also envisioned that it would "be used for much more" than just phone calls.Caroline Van Hasselt, [https://books.google.co.il/books?id=Wt8ulI7RV9oC&pg=PT247&lpg=PT247&dq=has+the+potential+to+become+all+pervasive+and+high+wire+act+and+carolyn&source=bl&ots=0SqsFCreXi&sig=INNHDPze4EOgQnwaxBKs4XHdwcI&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwiDyMaE7pDeAhURKuwKHeFGBcEQ6AEwAHoECAEQAQ#v=onepage&q=has%20the%20potential%20to%20become%20all%20pervasive%20and%20high%20wire%20act%20and%20carolyn&f=false ''High Wire Act: Ted Rogers and the Empire That Debt Built''], Mississauga, Ontario: [[John Wiley & Sons]], 2008, Chapters 12 and 14. When cell phones became widely available, it paid big dividends for Margolese.Katy Bachman, "Space Invaders: The Next Wave," ''[[Mediaweek]]'', April 12, 1999.{{cite news |last1=Bary |first1=Andrew |title=Siren Song |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB882600175119294500 |publisher=''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' |date=22 December 1997}} His company joined with [[Rogers Communications]] to form Cantel (a contraction of the name Canadian Telecom). Cantel would ultimately become [[Rogers Wireless]], as of 2012 the largest cellular company in Canada, with over 9.3 million subscribers and revenues over $7 billion.Ian Hardy, [http://mobilesyrup.com/2012/07/24/rogers-q2-2012-wireless-subscriber-base-reaches-9351-million-revenue-increases-1/ “Rogers Q2 2012: Wireless subscriber base reaches 9.351 million, revenue increases 1%,”] Mobile Syrup, July 24, 2012.Hugh Thompson, [http://www.digitalhome.ca/2011/02/rogers-reports-year-end-results/ “Rogers reports year end results,”] Digital Home, February 18, 2011. Margolese cashed out of the company in 1989 to found his next venture. ==Satellite radio== ===Sirius XM Radio=== Following a brief, unsuccessful stint in Israel struggling to land a license for his new cellular consortium Teletec, Margolese moved to New York City in 1990 and purchased control of a newly formed venture named CD Radio Inc.Peter Passell, [https://www.nytimes.com/1994/11/27/business/technology-coast-to-coast-radio-without-squawk-or-fade.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm “Coast-to-Coast Radio Without Squawk or Fade,”] ''[[New York Times]]'', November 27, 1994.[http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0008/06/bun.00.html “Business Unusual”] (transcript), [[CNN]], August 6, 2000. He served as chairman and CEO of the satellite radio company. Margolese believed that, like cable TV, satellite radio would find an audience willing to pay for variety. The primary obstacle faced by CD Radio and then Sirius was resistance from the [[Federal Communications Commission]] (FCC), who were under pressure from the [[National Association of Broadcasters]], who felt threatened by the competition. In 1997, the FCC granted both CD Radio and [[XM Satellite Radio]] licenses to use a part of the [[S band|S-band spectrum]], costing CD Radio $83 million. In 1999, Margolese changed the name of CD Radio to [[Sirius Satellite Radio]], so as not to be identified with the outdated technology of compact discs.Steve Warren, [https://books.google.com/books?id=s0jSxLqs-TwC&pg=PA166&lpg=PA166&dq=david+margolese+nasa&source=bl&ots=WpFylu92uc&sig=plcaG60sXIDezHp2OcZs5CR6zbA&hl=en&sa=X&ei=apQmUPbzKeTZ6wGg5oHAAw&ved=0CEYQ6AEwAzgK#v=onepage&q=david%20margolese%20nasa&f=false ''Radio: The Book''], 4th Edition, Burlington, MA: [[Focal Press]], 2005, p. 166. Margolese raised $1.8 billion to launch Sirius.Chris Jordan, [http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1452145/ins-outs-satellite-radio.jhtml “For More And More Music Fans, Satellite Radio Is Heaven Sent,”] [[MTV.com]], February 5, 2002.Nancy Dillon, [https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-79186364.html “CEO Leaves New York Satellite Radio Company,”] ''[[New York Daily News]]'', October 17, 2001. Some of the money was obtained by gaining exclusive rights from [[Ford]], [[Chrysler]], [[BMW]] and [[Mercedes-Benz]] to feature Sirius in their automobiles.Charles Graeber, [https://www.wired.com/2001/02/radio-star-rising/ “Radio Star Rising,”] ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'', February 2001. Along with co-founder and former [[NASA]] engineer [[Robert Briskman]], Margolese oversaw the development of the custom satellites, receivers and other technologies to bring satellite radio to consumers.Nancy Dillon, [http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/money/beaming-radio-high-tech-fast-lane-article-1.875098 “Beaming Radio Into High-Tech Fast Lane,”] ''[[New York Daily News]]'', June 5, 2000. Margolese also designed Sirius’s $40 million headquarters at [[Rockefeller Center]] in Manhattan. According to Margolese, each satellite cost about a quarter-billion dollars to build, insure and launch.Tim Moran, [https://www.nytimes.com/2000/09/22/automobiles/the-space-race-for-satellite-radio-is-picking-up-speed.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm “The Space Race for Satellite Radio Is Picking Up Speed,”] ''[[New York Times]]'', September 22, 2000. At the end of 2000, Sirius launched its third satellite into space, from the [[Baikonur Cosmodrome]] in [[Kazakhstan]]. In November 2001, Margolese stepped down as CEO, remaining as chairman until November 2003, with Sirius issuing a statement thanking him "for his great vision, leadership and dedication in creating both Sirius and the satellite radio industry."[https://www.fleetfinancials.com/49821/david-margolese-steps-down-as-sirius-ceo "David Margolese Steps Down as Sirius CEO,"] [[PRNewswire]], October 16, 2001.David Hinckley, [http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/entertainment/satellite-entry-grabs-early-lead-article-1.926833 “Satellite Entry Grabs Early Lead,”] ''[[New York Daily News]]'', October 20, 2001.Kenneth Hein, [http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising-branding/scott-greenstein-sirius-satellite-radio-94482 “Scott Greenstein, Sirius Satellite Radio,”] ''[[Adweek]]'', October 10, 2005. Sirius acquired XM in 2008, becoming [[Sirius XM Radio]].Eliot Van Buskirk, [https://www.wired.com/listening_post/2008/07/sirius-xm-compl/ “Sirius, XM Complete Merger,”] ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'', July 29, 2008. Through 2013, Sirius XM has reported 25.6 million subscribers, up 7% from the previous year, and revenues of $3.8 billion, up 12% from the previous year.Georg Szalai, [http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/sirius-xm-reports-record-quarterly-676898 "Sirius XM Reports Record Quarterly Revenue,"] ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'', February 4, 2014. In 2012, one of Sirius's original backup satellites, now decommissioned, was donated for display to the [[Smithsonian Institution]]’s [[National Air and Space Museum]].[http://newsdesk.si.edu/releases/sirius-fm-4-broadcasting-satellite-donated-smithsonian-s-national-air-and-space-museum "Sirius FM-4 Broadcasting Satellite Donated to the Smithsonian's National Air and Space Museum,"] newsdesk.si.edu, October 18, 2012. ==Honors== Margolese was named one of ten finalists for the 1999 Entrepreneur of the Year by [[Harvard Business School]].[http://archive.is/nihre “Harvard Business School Club Selects David C. McCourt, Chairman/CEO of RCN Corporation, as Top Entrepreneur,”] CosmoCom press release, February 22, 1999. He was inducted into NASA’s [[Space Technology Hall of Fame]] in 2002.{{cite web |title=Satellite Radio Technology |url=https://www.spacefoundation.org/what-we-do/space-technology-hall-fame/inducted-technologies/satellite-radio-technology |website=spacefoundation.org |accessdate=18 October 2018}} ==Personal life== In 2002, Margolese moved to Israel, fulfilling a lifelong dream. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.davidmargolese.com/ Official website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Margolese, David}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Vancouver]] [[Category:Canadian Jews]] [[Category:Canadian radio executives]] [[Category:Canadian radio company founders]] [[Category:Canadian emigrants to Israel]] [[Category:Israeli Jews]] [[Category:Businesspeople in telecommunications]] [[Category:Rogers Communications]] [[Category:Sirius Satellite Radio]] [[Category:Sirius XM Radio]] [[Category:University of British Columbia alumni]]

{{Infobox political party |name = Deutscher Verband |native_name = German Association |foundation = 1919 |dissolution = 1926 |successor = [[South Tyrolean People's Party]]
(not legal successor) |ideology = |colorcode = Black |country = Trentino-Alto Adige/Südtirol }} The '''Deutscher Verband''' was a coalition of bourgeois German speaking political parties that was formed in [[South Tyrol]] in 1919 after the region was annexed by Italy. It was a merger of the Catholic [[Tiroler Volkspartei]] and the liberal nationalist [[Deutschfreiheitliche Partei]]. The German speaking [[Social Democrats]], for their part, joined with the [[Italian Socialist Party]].Othmar Parteli: ''Südtirol (1918–1970)'', in: ''Geschichte des Landes Tirol.'' Band 4/2. Athesia, Bozen 1988 At the [[Italian general election, 1921]] the coalition won 90% of the vote and elected all four of the deputies that were allotted to the region. The first leader of the Deutscher Verband was [[Eduard Reut-Nicolussi]].http://www.andreas-hofer-bund.de/sandwirtsbrief_1.htm In 1923 he was replaced by the lawyer [[Karl Tinzl]]. The most important press organ of the DV, until its prohibition, was the ''[[Tiroler]]'' (after 1923, ''[[Der Landsmann]]'').{{citation/core|Surname1=Stefan Lechner|EditorSurname1= [[Hannes Obermair]], Stephanie Risse, [[Carlo Romeo (Historiker, 1962)|Carlo Romeo]]|Periodical=Regionale Zivilgesellschaft in Bewegung. Festschrift für Hans Heiss|Title=Die Erste Option: die Vergabe der italienischen Staatsbürgerschaft an die Südtiroler in Folge der Annexion 1920|Series=Cittadini innanzi tutto|Publisher=Folio Verlag|PublicationPlace=Wien-Bozen|At=pp. 219–236, Bezug S. 223|ISBN=978-3-85256-618-4|Date=2012|language=German }} The DV as banned along with the rest of the non-Fascist parties in 1926. After 1945, the political tradition of the DV was continued by the [[South Tyrolean People's Party]], which had the same leaders, and also used the [[edelweiss]] as its election symbol. == References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:Political parties established in 1919]] [[Category:Political parties disestablished in 1926]] [[Category:Defunct political parties in South Tyrol]] [[Category:Defunct political party alliances in Italy]] {{italy-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} The [[Labour Party (UK)|British Labour Party's]] '''Economic Advisory Committee''' was in 2015-16 a group of economists, described as experts on globalisation, inequality and innovation,<ref name="NS01">{{cite web |last=Boland |first=Stephanie |title=Who is advising Jeremy Corbyn on economics? |publisher=''[[New Statesman]]'' |date=28 September 2015 |url=http://www.newstatesman.com/politics/economy/2015/09/who-advising-jeremy-corbyn-economics |accessdate=11 March 2016}}</ref> convened by [[Shadow Chancellor of the Exchequer|Shadow Chancellor]] [[John McDonnell (politician)|John McDonnell]] and reporting to [[Leader of the Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party Leader]] [[Jeremy Corbyn]], announced on 27 September 2015 at the [[Labour Party (UK) Conference#2015 Brighton|Labour Party Conference in Brighton]],<ref name="BBC01">{{cite web |last= |first= |title=Labour conference: Economists Piketty and Stiglitz to advise Corbyn |publisher=''[[BBC News]]'' |date=27 September 2015 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-34374349 |accessdate=11 March 2016}}</ref> and intended to meet on a quarterly basis to discuss and develop ideas around the official economic strategy to be advocated by the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]],<ref name="LL01">{{cite web |last= |first= |title=Corbyn reveals big names in new Economic Advisory Committee |publisher=''LabourList'' |date=27 September 2015 |url=http://labourlist.org/2015/09/corbyn-reveals-big-names-in-new-economic-advisory-committee/ |accessdate=11 March 2016}}</ref> but not to set policy.<ref name="FT01">{{cite web |last=Giles |first=Chris |title=Team McDonnell: meet Labour’s seven economic advisers |publisher=''[[Financial Times]]'' |date=28 September 2015 |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/96534d2e-65c1-11e5-a28b-50226830d644.html#axzz42dSycGKx |accessdate=11 March 2016}}</ref> It has been described a way to give the Shadow Chancellor defensive cover.<ref name="FT02">{{cite web |last=Pickard |first=Jim |title=Enfant terrible of hard left learns language of conciliation |publisher=''[[Financial Times]]'' |date=29 January 2016 |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/28a5ce14-c5b1-11e5-b3b1-7b2481276e45.html#axzz43TvcdSij |accessdate=20 March 2016}}</ref>
In June 2016 Pickett and Blanchflower left, and the remaining members of the Economic Advisory Committee announced they had decided to postpone any further meetings, in the wake of the resignation of numerous members of the [[Shadow Cabinet of Jeremy Corbyn|Shadow Cabinet]] in protest over [[Jeremy Corbyn]]'s leadership.
==Membership== The committee originally consisted of seven members, described by then ''[[BBC News]]'' Economics Editor [[Robert Peston]] as, "some of the world's most influential left-wing economists".<ref name="BBC02">{{cite web |last=Peston |first=Robert |title=Corbynomics' Thatcher moment |publisher=''[[BBC News]]'' |date=27 September 2015 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-34376085 |accessdate=11 March 2016}}</ref>
*[[David Blanchflower]], Professor, [[Dartmouth College]] and former member of the [[Monetary Policy Committee]], described by [[Channel 4]] Economics Editor [[Paul Mason (journalist)|Paul Mason]] as a, "scourge of austerity".<ref name="C401">{{cite web |last=Mason |first=Paul |title=John McDonnell: what will Corbynomics look like? |publisher=''[[Channel 4 News]]'' |date=14 September 2015 |url=http://blogs.channel4.com/paul-mason-blog/john-mcdonnell-corbynomics/4237 |accessdate=20 March 2016}}</ref> (resigned 28 June 2016 stating that Corbyn should step down) *[[Mariana Mazzucato]], Professor, [[University of Sussex]], whose ideas on ''smart'' state direction through a national investment bank or sovereign wealth fund have impressed [[Vince Cable]] and [[Chi Onwurah]].<ref name="C401" /> *Anastasia Nesvetailova, Professor, [[City University London]] *[[Thomas Piketty]], Professor, [[Paris School of Economics]] (resigned 29 June 2016 due to time constraints)<ref>http://bfmbusiness.bfmtv.com/monde/le-francais-thomas-piketty-claque-la-porte-du-parti-travailliste-anglais-998350.html "Le Français Thomas Piketty claque la porte du parti travailliste anglais" 29 June 2016. </ref> *[[Ann Pettifor]], Director, Policy Research in Macroeconomics (PRIME), a debt campaigner drawn from what Channel 4 Economics Editor Paul Mason describes as a “post” socialist think tank.<ref name="C401" /> *[[Joseph Stiglitz]], Professor, [[Columbia University]] and recipient of the 2001 [[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences]] *[[Simon Wren-Lewis]], Professor, [[University of Oxford]]
The inclusion of Piketty and Stilgitz was seen as a particular coup for the Labour Party leadership due to their breakthrough success in mainstream publishing,<ref name="BI01">{{cite web |last=Williams-Grut |first=Oscar |title=Meet the team shaping the Labour Party's 'New Economics' |publisher=''[[Business Insider]]'' |date=28 September 2015 |url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/jeremy-corbyn-and-john-mcdonnells-economic-advisors-2015-9 |accessdate=11 March 2016}}</ref> while the absence of [[Richard Murphy (political economist)|Richard Murphy]], who had advised Corbyn on his cornerstone policy of [[People's Quantitative Easing]] was noted.<ref name="IBT01">{{cite web |last=Silvera |first=Ian |title=Rock star academic Thomas Piketty joins Jeremy Corbyn's economy team |publisher=''[[International Business Times]]'' |date=27 September 2015 |url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/rock-star-academic-thomas-piketty-joins-jeremy-corbyns-economy-team-1521407 |accessdate=11 March 2016}}</ref>
Following the formation of the committee, Economics Editors [[Robert Peston]], then of ''[[BBC News]]'', and Chris Giles, of the ''[[Financial Times]]'', confirmed that the seven members were unified in their opposition to the spending cuts of [[Chancellor of the Exchequer|Chancellor]] [[George Osborne]],<ref name="FT01" /><ref name="BBC02" /> although the latter warned that they had less in common in other areas.<ref name="FT01" />
==History==
===Formation=== Regarding the formation of the committee, its convener, [[John McDonnell (politician)|John McDonnell]] later stated, as part of a series of public debates to present his Party's "New Economics", that the Economic Advisory Committee had initially been set up to conduct reviews into public institutions including [[HM Treasury]], the [[Monetary Policy Committee]] and [[HM Revenue and Customs]], and that it was due to the surprising number of people at the [[Labour Party (UK) Conference#2015 Brighton|2015 Labour Party Conference in Brighton]] who felt the Labour Party should be an anti-austerity party that the policy of anti-austerity was set.<ref name="Ind01">{{cite web |last=Sheffield |first=Hazel |title=Labour's economic policy will rest on two watchwords: democracy and decentralisation, John McDonnell says |publisher=''[[The Independent]]'' |date=17 February 2016 |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/labours-economic-policy-will-rest-on-two-watchwords-democracy-and-decentralisation-john-mcdonnell-a6878576.html |accessdate=11 March 2016}}</ref> Committee member [[David Blanchflower]], who confirmed he was undertaking an independent review of the Bank of England for the shadow chancellor, had however stated that opposition to austerity on its own was not enough and that it would take some time to produce a coherent new economic strategy that party members share.<ref name="NS02">{{cite web |last=Blanchflower |first=David |title=Opposing austerity is not enough – Labour’s leaders need lessons in economics, fast |publisher=''[[New Statesman]]'' |date=27 January 2016 |url=http://www.newstatesman.com/politics/economy/2016/01/opposing-austerity-not-enough-labour-s-leaders-need-lessons-economics-fast |accessdate=11 March 2016}}</ref>
The formation of the committee, according to [[Robert Peston]], then ''[[BBC News]]'' Economics Editor, went some way to answering the common charge that [[Jeremy Corbyn]] and [[John McDonnell (politician)|John McDonnell]] were "left-wing dinosaurs" and would ensure, "a properly emotional debate" between the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] and the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] about, "how to maximise growth and prosperity".<ref name="BBC02" /> Peston went on to contend that this was the first time since [[Leader of the Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party Leader]] [[Margaret Thatcher]] had drawn upon the ideas of [[Milton Friedman]] and [[Friedrich Hayek]], that a leading British political party had, "attempted to establish an economic ideology outside the mainstream".<ref name="BBC02" /> Chris Giles, ''[[The Financial Times]]'' Economics Editor, countered this claim by referencing relationships between former [[Leader of the Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party Leaders]] and economists, such as [[Neil Kinnock]] with [[John Eatwell]] and [[Piero Sraffa]], and [[Gordon Brown]] with [[Robert Reich]] and [[Richard B. Freeman]], as well as [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] [[Chancellor of the Exchequer|Chancellor]] [[George Osborne]] with [[Alan Budd]] and [[Kenneth Rogoff]].<ref name="FT01" /> Although, as Peston concludes, none of these had formed a similar committee.<ref name="BBC02" />
===First Meeting=== The first meeting of the committee was convened at 2pm on 12 November 2015, at Labour Party’s Brewers Green headquarters, with [[Shadow Secretary of State for Business, Innovation and Skills|Shadow Business Secretary]] [[Angela Eagle]], [[Shadow Chief Secretary to the Treasury|Shadow Chief Secretary]] [[Seema Malhotra]] and the entire Shadow Treasury team in attendance.<ref name="LL02">{{cite web |last= |first= |title=What’s happening at the first meeting of Labour’s star-studded Economic Advisory Committee? |publisher=''LabourList'' |date=12 November 2015 |url=http://labourlist.org/2015/11/whats-happenening-at-the-first-meeting-of-labours-star-studded-economic-advisory-committee/ |accessdate=11 March 2016}}</ref> At the meeting, [[Simon Wren-Lewis]] spoke about fiscal policy, [[Mariana Mazzucato]] about strategic investment, and [[Ann Pettifor]] about the importance of a strong economic narrative.<ref name="LL02" /> Although Anastasia Nesvetailova and [[David Blanchflower]] were also in attendance, the latter via [[Skype]],<ref name="LL02" /> neither of the two most high-profile members, [[Thomas Piketty]] and [[Joseph Stiglitz]], were present at this initial meeting.<ref name="NS03">{{cite web |last=Chakelian |first=Anoosh |title="Labour must get real about the economy": is Corbyn’s economic advisory board unravelling? |publisher=''[[New Statesman]]'' |date=27 January 2016 |url=http://www.newstatesman.com/politics/economy/2016/01/labour-must-get-real-about-economy-corbyn-s-economic-advisory-board |accessdate=11 March 2016}}</ref>
===First "New Economics" Public Debates=== On 26 January 2016, committee member [[Mariana Mazzucato]], gave the first of the ''[[New Economics Tour]]'', which had been announced by [[John McDonnell (politician)|John McDonnell]] with the intention of broadening the political debate.<ref name="LL03">{{cite web |last= |first= |title=John McDonnell launches ‘New Economics’ public debate tour |publisher=''LabourList'' |date=18 January 2016 |url=http://labourlist.org/2016/01/john-mcdonnell-launches-new-economics-public-debate-tour/ |accessdate=11 March 2016}}</ref>
In January 2016, coinciding with the start of the party's series of public debates presenting their "New Economics", it was reported in the ''[[New Statesman]]'' that the committee had only met once and members had accused the party of having “stupid ideas” about economic policy.<ref name="NS03" /> In the article which the report was based upon [[David Blanchflower]], committee member and ''[[New Statesman]]'' economics editor, confirmed that although the committee had only met once the plan was to convene every quarter from then on and that the "silly stuff" he referred to was companies not being able to pay dividends if they don’t do certain things.<ref name="NS02" /> Blanchflower, who admitted that it was early days and that the new Labour Party still did not have many economic policies to speak of, nonetheless confirmed that economists in the group were smart, left-leaning and credible, and that it was time to start thinking about how Labour could become a credible opposition.<ref name="NS02" />
===Leadership crisis=== Blanchflower quit the panel and said he would also wind up his review of the role of the [[Bank of England]] on 28 June 2016 following the mass resignations of the Shadow Cabinet, joining them in calling for Corbyn to step down.<ref name="panelshutdown">{{cite news|last1=Inman|first1=Phillip|title=Former Corbyn adviser Thomas Piketty criticises Labour's 'weak' EU fight|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jun/29/thomas-piketty-quits-as-adviser-to-jeremy-corbyn|accessdate=27 July 2016|publisher=Guardian|date=29 June 2016}}</ref> Piketty revealed that he had also left the panel in June, citing work commitments. He also criticised Labour's "very weak" referendum campaign to remain in the EU but said this was not a factor in his decision.<ref name="panelshutdown" />
Some other members of the panel, including Mazzucato, Pettifor and Wren-Lewis issued a statement saying the panel had agreed to delay further meetings as a result of mass resignations over the leadership of Jeremy Corbyn. They also criticised the Labour leadership over the EU campaign, but said they saw their role as "providing advice to the Labour party as a whole, and not as an endorsement of particular individuals within" and would be "honoured" to serve the party in future after the leadership situation was resolved<ref name="panelshutdown" /> [[Simon Wren-Lewis]] later joined with Blanchflower endorsing [[Owen Smith]] over Corbyn for the leadership on 31 July 2016.<ref>{{cite news |last=Mason |first=Rowena |title=Former economic advisers to Corbyn back rival for Labour leader |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jul/31/economic-advisers-jeremy-corbyn-cant-win-next-election-owen-smith |accessdate=1 August 2016 |publisher=Guardian |date=31 July 2016}}</ref>
==Policies== ===People's Quantitative Easing=== Shortly after the formation of the committee, [[Robert Peston]] contended that the composition of the panel signalled that [[People's Quantitative Easing]], the policy of requiring the [[Bank of England]] to print money to finance government investment, which had up to that point been considered the cornerstone of [[Corbynomics|Jeremy Corbyn's economic policy]], was probably dead, as he felt that while this particular group of economists would, "back the notion of the government taking advantage of prevailing low interest rates to borrow considerably more for investment in infrastructure," they would not support the ultra formulation of the policy, "for fear that the anti-inflationary credentials of the Bank of England would be destroyed", and that if the policy survived it would be as, "a contingent rainy-day monetary tool, for when the economy is next in direst straits."<ref name="BBC02" />
== References == {{reflist|2}}
{{Jeremy Corbyn}} {{UK Labour Party}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Economic Advisory Committee}} [[Category:Jeremy Corbyn]] [[Category:2015 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:2015 in British politics]] [[Category:Global policy organizations]]

revision.text:
{{Expand French|Drapeau de l'Alsace|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox flag | Name = Flag of Alsace | Article = | Image = Flag of Alsace (historical).svg | Alt = | Noborder = <!-- Leave blank for rectangular flag; for non-rectangular flag, type "no". --> | Nickname = ''{{lang|gsw|Rot un Wiss}}'' | Morenicks = | Use = <!-- Required for |Symbol --> | Symbol = <!-- |Use="6-digit FIAV usage code" is required. --> | Proportion= | Adoption = 11th century | Design = Red and white | Designer = [[Gerard, Duke of Lorraine|Gérard d'Alsace, Duke of Lorraine]] }} {{Alsace sidebar}} [[File:Flag of Alsace (old).svg|thumb|The official flag of [[Alsace]] 1949–2008, representing the two {{lang|fr|[[département]]s}} of {{lang|fr|[[Haut-Rhin]]}} and {{lang|fr|[[Bas-Rhin]]}}]] [[File:Flag of Alsace.svg|thumb|The official flag of [[Alsace]] 2008–present]]
The '''flag of Alsace''' ([[Alsatian dialect|Alsatian]]: '''''{{lang|gsw|Rot un Wiss}}''''' or '''''{{lang|gsw|Rot-un-Wiss}}''''', "red and white") is the original red and white [[flag]] of the region, and can be traced to the red and white [[banner]] of [[Gerard, Duke of Lorraine]] in the 11th century.
Particularly since the introduction of new [[France|French]] region [[Grand Est]], the traditional ''{{lang|gsw|Rot un Wiss}}'' flag of [[Alsace]] has been widely promoted by the advocates of the [[Alsace independence movement|Alsace autonomous movement]].
== History ==
=== ''{{lang|gsw|Rot un Wiss}}'' (from the 11th century) === The original flag of Alsace, the ''{{lang|gsw|Rot un Wiss}}'', dates back to the red and white [[banner]]<ref>http://www.genealogie-bisval.net/Images/Lorraine.gif</ref> of [[Gerard, Duke of Lorraine]] in the 11th century.
Red and white colours are commonly found on the coat of arms of Alsatian cities such as [[Strasbourg]], [[Mulhouse]] and [[Sélestat]],<ref>http://www.unserland.org/dossiers/breve-histoire-dun-drapeau-alsacien/</ref> and additionally of many [[Swiss]] cities, especially in the region of [[Basel-Landschaft]].
=== Departments flag (1949–2008) === Perhaps as the ''{{lang|gsw|Rot un Wiss}}'' marks the [[Germany|Germanic]] roots of Alsace, it was replaced in 1949 by a new flag, representing the union of the two ''{{lang|fr|[[département]]s}}'' of {{lang|fr|[[Haut-Rhin]]}} and {{lang|fr|[[Bas-Rhin]]}}, however without real historical relevance. It was subsequently modified to a slightly different appearance, yet also representing the two departments.
== Controversy == There is controversy around the recognition of the Alsatian flag.
With the purpose of "Francosizing" the region, the ''{{lang|gsw|Rot un Wiss}}'' has not been recognised by the French government. Some French politicians have erroneously called this a "[[Nazi]] invention" — while the ''{{lang|gsw|Rot un Wiss}}'' is still known as the real historical [[emblem]] of the region by most of the population and the departments' parliaments.
Subsequently, the ''{{lang|gsw|Rot un Wiss}}'' has been widely used during protests against the creation of a new "super-region" [[Grand Est]], gathering [[Champagne-Ardennes]], [[Lorraine (region)|Lorraine]] and Alsace, namely on [[Replicas of the Statue of Liberty#Colmar|Colmar's statue of liberty]].<ref>http://france3-regions.francetvinfo.fr/alsace/2014/11/16/colmar-une-statu-de-la-liberte-en-rot-und-wiss-593102.html</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2017}} {{Infobox spaceflight | name = Intelsat V F-3 → Intelsat 503 | image = | image_caption = | mission_type = [[Communications satellite|Communication]] | operator = [[Intelsat]] | website = | COSPAR_ID = 1981-119A{{cite web|url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1981-119A|title=INTELSAT 5 F-3|publisher=National Space Science Data Center|accessdate=April 22, 2017}} | SATCAT = 12994 | mission_duration = 17 years | spacecraft_bus = [[Spacebus|Intelsat-V]] bus | manufacturer = [[Ford Aerospace]] | BOL_mass = {{convert|1012|kg|lb}} | launch_mass = {{convert|1928.2|kg|lb}} | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|December 15, 1981, 23:35|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = [[Atlas-Centaur|Atlas SLV-3D Centaur-D1AR]] | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Launch Complex 36|LC-36B]] | launch_contractor = | entered_service = | disposal_type = Decommissioned | deactivated = {{end-date|January 1998}} | orbit_epoch = December 15, 1981 | orbit_reference = [[Geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Geostationary orbit|Geostationary]] | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|165|km}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|35947|km}} | orbit_inclination = 23.7 degrees | orbit_eccentricity = 0.73207 | orbit_period = 633.5 minutes | orbit_longitude = | apsis = gee | trans_band = 21 [[C band (IEEE)|C-band]]
4 {{Ku band}} | trans_frequency = | trans_capacity = | trans_coverage = | trans_TWTA = | trans_EIRP = | trans_HPBW = | programme = ''Intelsat V'' | previous_mission = [[Intelsat V F-2]] | next_mission = [[Intelsat V F-4]] }} [[File:Atlas-Centaur launches with one INTELSAT V satellite.jpg|thumb|left|caption|190px|Launch of Intelsat V F-3.]] '''Intelsat 503''', previously named '''Intelsat V F-3''', was a [[communications satellite]] operated by [[Intelsat]]. Launched in 1981, it was the third of fifteen [[Intelsat V]] satellites to be launched. The Intelsat V series was constructed by [[Ford Aerospace]], based on the [[Spacebus|Intelsat-V]] [[satellite bus]]. Intelsat V F-2 was part of an advanced series of satellites designed to provide greater telecommunications capacity for [[Intelsat]]'s global network. The satellite was deactivated on January 1998. The satellite was successfully launched into space on December 15, 1981, at 23:35 UTC, by means of an [[Atlas-Centaur|Atlas SLV-3D Centaur-D1AR]] vehicle from the [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]], Florida, United States. It had a launch mass of 1,928 kg. The Intelsat 503 was equipped with 4 [[Ku-band]] transponders more 21 [[C band (IEEE)|C-band]] [[transponder]]s for 12,000 audio circuits and 2 TV channels. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Portal|Spaceflight}} {{Intelsat}} {{Orbital launches in 1981}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1981]] [[Category:Intelsat satellites]] [[Category:1981 in spaceflight]] {{US-spacecraft-stub}}

revision.text:
The '''Liechtensteiner Volksblatt''' is the older of the two daily newspapers in [[Liechtenstein]]. It is published by the Liechtensteiner Volksblatt AG, and as of 2015, had a circulation of 9,000 copies. The Thursday edition is distributed as a large print run, with an estimated circulation of 21,000 copies. <sup>[1]</sup> The editorial office is located in [[Schaan]].
== History ==
The newspaper was first published on 16 August 1878 <sup>[2]</sup> as the ''Press Association Liechtensteiner Volksblatt''. The Royal Chaplain Johann Fetz was the founder and first editor, serving in that capacity until 1884.<sup>[3]</sup> Up until 1918, it was published as a weekly newspaper, until it began printing twice weekly until 1919. The company gradually increased its rate of publication, from three editions per week starting in 1927, expanding to four in 1962, and then five times a week in 1978. Since January 1985, the paper has printed every day, except Sunday.
The Oberland newspaper is generally considered to have a conservative outlook, and regularly agrees with the positions of the reigning [[Prince of Liechtenstein]], and the [[Progressive Citizens' Party]]. Since September 2006, the paper has been published by "Liechtensteiner Volksblatt AG", a private publishing house which emerged from the former Press Club. In October 2006, the Vorarlberg media entrepreneur Eugen Russ (Vorarlberger Medienhaus <sup>[4]) also holds a minority stake in the publishing house.</sup> The majority shares are still in possession of the Royal Family of Liechtenstein.
The ''Liechtensteiner Volksblatt'' is financed through subscriptions and the sale of advertisements. The newspaper is published in the German language, and is primarily covers current affairs in Liechtenstein, though also providing some coverage of Switzerland and Austria.
== Structure == The ''Liechtensteiner Volksblatt'' is usually organised into eight sections: * The title page, with current news * News in Liechtenstein * European politics, as well as some global coverage * Business and financial section * Sports * Culture and arts * Weather and industry advertisements * Panorama
== Literature == * Wilfried Marxer: ''Media in Liechtenstein: structural analysis of the media landscape in a small state.'' Publishing the Liechtenstein Academic Society, 2004 {{ISBN|978-3-72111057-9}}.
== External links == *[http://www.volksblatt.li/ Liechtensteiner Volksblatt ] * Online Archive of the Liechtenstein State Library (searchable by 2005, available online until 1950.)
== References == # ↑ <sup>high jumping after:a b</sup> ''Key figures at a glance.'' In: Site of ''Liechtenstein'' Volksblatt, p. 3 (PDF; 3 kB). # High jump↑ According to Daniel Quaderer: ''Liechtenstein media landscape.'' In: ''Liechtensteiner Vaterland.'' 25 April 2014, and S. 27 (Supplement: ''One Hundred Years of'' News). # High jump↑ Norbert Jansen: ''priest, journalist, historian'' (Memento of 2 February 2014 ''Internet'' Archive). This is a '''list of cities in [[Association of Southeast Asian Nations]] (ASEAN)'''.
==Largest cities==
This list features the most populous cities in ASEAN. Population figures were taken from within the city proper only. See the article on each city for sources. Myanmar data is the least reliable and subject to revision. It is important to note, that the general area of Metro Manila has been divided into its political cities and is not counted as one urban city in this ranking. Therefore the metropolis' true population is not reflected in this ranking (it would otherwise be first or second in population size, depending on the definition of Jakarta's true city area).

revision.text:
{{Infobox Union |name= LO
Norwegian Confederation of Trade Unions |country= [[Norway]] |affiliation= [[International Trade Union Confederation|ITUC]], [[European Trade Union Confederation|ETUC]], [[Council of Nordic Trade Unions|NFS]] |members= 850,000 |full_name= Norwegian Confederation of Trade Unions |native_name= Landsorganisasjonen i Norge, LO |image= [[File:Landsorganisasjonen i Norge (logo).jpg]] |founded= 1899 |current= |head= |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= |merged_into= |office= [[Oslo]], [[Norway]] |people=[[Leaders of the Norwegian Confederation of Trade Unions|President]] [[Hans-Christian Gabrielsen]] |website= [http://www.lo.no/ Official website] |footnotes= }} [[File:Folkets Hus Oslo 2007.jpg|thumb|The headquarters of Norwegian Confederation of Trade Unions, LO (Folkets Hus) at [[Youngstorget]] in [[Oslo]]]] The '''Norwegian Confederation of Trade Unions''' ({{lang-no|Landsorganisasjonen i Norge}}, LO) is a [[national trade union center]], decidedly the largest and probably the most influential [[umbrella organization]] of [[trade union|labour union]]s in [[Norway]]. The 21 national unions affiliated to the LO have almost 900,000 members of a Norwegian population of 5 million. The majority of affiliated unions organizes traditional blue collar workers, but the largest affiliate is the [[Norwegian Union of Municipal and General Employees]] which makes up more than a third of all members.Ole Storeng (3 May 2013): [http://www.aftenposten.no/meninger/kommentarer/Lederskifte-gir-ingen-revolusjon-7193139.html#.UYfdLcrJIgQ Lederskifte gir ingen revolusjon] {{no icon}} ''[[Aftenposten]]'', retrieved 6 May 2013 LO is affiliated to the [[International Trade Union Confederation|ITUC]] and the [[ETUC]]. [[Gerd Kristiansen]] was elected leader on 6 May 2013 for a four-year period. It was named the Workers' National Trade Union ({{lang-no|Arbeidernes Faglige Landsorganisasjon}}, AFL) from 1899 to 1957.{{cite book|last=Gran|first=Thorvald|title=The State in the Modernization Process. The case of Norway 1850-1970|publisher=Ad Notam Gyldendal|location=Oslo|year=1994|page=18|url=https://bora.uib.no/bitstream/1956/3406/1/The%20State%20in%20the%20Modernization%20Process.pdf|accessdate=7 November 2009|language=Norwegian}} [[Ingvald B. Aase]] served as treasurer from 1934 until his death in 1948.{{cite web|url=http://www.nsd.uib.no/polsys/index.cfm?urlname=storting&lan=&MenuItem=N1_1&ChildItem=&State=collapse&UttakNr=33&person=10056|title=Ingvald Berentin Aase|publisher=Norwegian Social Science Data Services (NSD)|language=Norwegian|accessdate=13 November 2010}} The organization owns the [[Norwegian Labour Movement Archives and Library]].{{cite journal|last=Halvorsen|first=Solveig|title=The Norwegian Labour Movement Archives And Library|journal=Saothar|year=1995|volume=20|pages=105–107|jstor=23197247}} It is considered as being part of the "Labour Sphere" in Norway. == Affiliated unions == *Norwegian [[United Federation of Trade Unions]] (''Fellesforbundet'', FF) *[[Norwegian Engineers’ and Managers’ Association]] (''Forbundet for Ledelse og Teknikk, ''FLT) *[[Norwegian Union of General Workers]] (''Norsk Arbeidsmandsforbund '', NAF) *[[EL & IT Forbundet|The Electrician and IT Workers’ Union]] (El & IT) *[[Norwegian Union of Social Educators and Social Workers]] (''Fellesorganisasjonen'', FO) *[[Norwegian Prison and Probation Officers’ Union]] (''Norsk Fengsels- og Friomsorgsforbund'', NFF) *Norwegian [[Union of Employees in Commerce and Offices]] (''Handel og Kontor i Norge'', HK) *[[Norwegian Union of Railway Workers]] (''Norsk Jernbaneforbund'', NJF) *[[Norwegian Musicians’ Union]] (''Musikernes fellesorganisasjon'', NM) *[[Norwegian Union of Municipal and General Employees]] (''Fagforbundet'', NUMGE) *[[Norwegian Manualtherapist Association]] (''Norsk Manuellterapeutforening'') *[[National Union of Norwegian Locomotivemen]] (''Norsk Lokomotivmannsforbund'', NLF) *[[Norwegian Union of Food, Beverage and Allied Workers|Norwegian Food and Allied Workers’ Union]] (''Norsk Nærings- og Nytelsesmiddelarbeiderforbund'', NNN) *[[Norwegian Union of Military Officers]] (''Norges Offisersforbund'', NOF) *[[Industri Energi|Norwegian Union of Industry and Energy Workers]] (''Industri Energi'', IE) *[[Norwegian Post and Communications Union|Norwegian Union of Postal and Communication Workers]] (POSTKOM) *[[The Labour Press Union]] (''Arbeiderbevegelsens Presseforbund'') *[[Norwegian Seafarers' Union]] (''Norsk Sjømannsforbund'', NSF) *[[Norwegian Union of School Employees]] (''Skolenes Landsforbund'', SL) *[[Norwegian Civil Service Union]] (''Norsk Tjenestemannslag'', NTL) *[[Norwegian Transport Workers’ Union]] (''Norsk Transportarbeiderforbund'', NTF) *[[Norwegian Players’ Association]] (''Norske Idrettsutøveres Sentralorganisasjon'' NISO) *[[Cabin Crew Union Norway]] (''Norsk Kabinforening'')[http://www.lo.no/Sprak/English/News-articles/National-unions/ National Unions] LO ==See also== {{Portal|Organised labour}} *[[Leaders of the Norwegian Confederation of Trade Unions]] {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox radio station |image = |caption =On the occasion of Radio Choklate 104 FM (Odisha's no.1 FM station), completing 10 years, this logo was created to commemorate the event. |format = |owner =Sambad Group (Eastern Media Limited) |licensee = |airdate = |name = |city = |branding = |slogan =Dhum Mitha |frequency = |translator = |repeater = |language =Odia |erp = |area = Odisha, India |coordinates = |callsign_meaning = |sister_stations = |webcast = |website = {{URL|radiochoklate.com}} }} '''Radio Choklate''' 104 [[FM broadcasting|FM]] is [[Odisha]]’s no.1 radio channel launched and is a part of the Sambad Group (Eastern Media Limited). Radio Choklate provides service in Odisha, predominantly in the regional [[Odia language]] along with [[Hindi]] and English. It airs Odia and Hindi music, covers local news, popular trends and stories that cater to the human interest. It is part of [[Soumya Ranjan Patnaik]]'s Eastern Media Limited holdings.
The station was launched on 4 May 2007. In 2017 the station hosted the Choklate Awards show.
==Broadcasting== Radio Choklate is broadcast from [[Cuttack]] and [[Rourkela]] stations in Odisha at 104 FM frequency and live streamed via Radio Choklate Online [http://radiochoklateonline.com/ (www.radiochoklateonline.com]).
==Programmes==
Daily shows are listed below:
1. '''Stotra''': Early morning show consisting of shlokas, aired at 4 am
2. '''Punya Ra Nadi Tire''': Devotional show presented by RJ Arjya, aired at 5 am
3. '''Sakaala Ra Pahili Gaadi Re''': Morning show hosted by RJ Komal that gives out updates on weather, fashion, special occsions, festivals, traffic, etc, aired at 7 am
4. '''Baata Chaada, Anil Aasuchi''': Mid-morning show anchored by RJ Anil that includes chit-chat with people from various walks of life, aired at 10 am
5. '''Diary of a Housewife''': Monologue of a housewife, aired at 12 noon
6. '''Sei Jhuma Jhuma Golaapi Bela Re''': Anecdotes, stories, history, trivia of Ollywood and sometimes, Bollywood presented by RJ Niel, aired at 1 pm
7. '''Tuma Paeen Gita Tiye''': Listeners request RJ Nivy to play their songs, aired at 3 pm
8. '''Choklate Countdown''': RJs Komal & Anil present the latest Bollywood updates of the day, aired at 5 pm
9. '''Choklate 20-20''': RJ Nadeem presents top 20 songs of the day along with some trending informations of the day, aired at 8 pm
10. '''Prema Ra Formula''': All about love and relationships with RJ Sangram, aired at 10 pm
11. '''Sahara Ra Bati Sabu Libhi Gala Pare''': RJ Niel talks to listeners over phone, to interact with them on light topics, aired at 1 am
Weekend special shows are as follows:
1. '''Kalamandir Geetmala''': Aired every Fridat at 8 pm
2. '''Mu Tate Bhala Paaye Ete''': Love stories of celebrities from Bollywood and sometimes Ollywood as narrated by RJ Sangram, aired every Saturday 11 pm
3. '''Bhaya''': Horror show, aired every Saturday and Sunday at 10 pm
4. '''Asaadhaarana''': Talk show hosted by RJ Sangram, in conversation with individuals with an indomitable spirit, aired every Sunday at 8 am
5. '''Baabuna''': Aired every Sunday at 3 pm
6. '''Rangamancha''': Enactments and plays on various social issues, aired every Sunday at 9 pm
7. '''Eyi Maati Ra Itihaasa''': A show based on Strories of Odia Warriors, who fought for an independent odisha.
==Other== Radio Choklate released a music video for Holi celebrations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://odishasuntimes.com/radio-choklates-holi-music-video-a-must-add-to-your-festive-playlist/|title=Radio Choklate's Holi music video a must-add to your festive playlist - OdishaSunTimes.com|first=Odisha Sun Times|last=Bureau|website=odishasuntimes.com}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://radiochoklate.com/ Radio Choklate - Dhum Mitha]
{{Coord missing|Odisha}}
